events.event_description: U.S. West Coast refiners increased their purchased hydrogen from merchant suppliers by 29% to 550 MMcf/d, while on-site production fell 20% to 330 MMcf/d.
events.citation: From 2012 to 2022, hydrogen purchased by refiners in the region increased 29% to about 550 million cubic feet per day (MMcf/d). Over the same period, on-site refinery-produced hydrogen production from natural gas fell 20% to about 330 MMcf/d.

events.event_description: Merchant suppliers reached a record high of supplying 70% of U.S. refinery hydrogen demand, up from 63% in 2019.
events.citation: Merchant suppliers met 70% of U.S. refinery hydrogen demand in 2022, the highest percentage since we began publishing these data in 2009. For comparison, merchant suppliers met 63% of U.S. refinery hydrogen demand in 2019.

events.event_description: U.S. refining industry experienced significant increase in hydrogen demand due to ultra-low sulfur diesel (ULSD) phase-in for all on-road diesel.
events.citation: Hydrogen demand in the U.S. refining industry increased significantly from 2006 to 2010 as ultra-low sulfur diesel (ULSD) was phased in for all on-road diesel.

events.event_description: EIA study revealed that by-product hydrogen accounts for at least 50% of all hydrogen purchased by U.S. refineries and 30% of total refinery hydrogen needs not from by-product reforming.
events.citation: According to an internal 2018 EIA study, by-product hydrogen accounts for at least 50% of all hydrogen purchased by U.S. refineries and at least 30% of all hydrogen that refineries need that is not produced from by-product reforming.
